Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Continuous and Interrupted Suture Techniques for Biliary-Enteric Anastomosis

Trial_Design.evidence: In this single-centre randomised controlled trial, 82 patients scheduled for elective open BEA at University Hospital Dresden between January 2016 and September 2017 were randomised 1:1 to CS or IS groups.

Participants.evidence: 82 patients scheduled for elective open BEA at University Hospital Dresden

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to CS or IS groups

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare continuous suture (CS) and interrupted suture (IS) techniques for biliary-enteric anastomosis (BEA) by evaluating suture time and biliary complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was suture time, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using block randomisation with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Patients and outcome assessors were blinded, but surgeons were not.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 82 patients scheduled for elective open BEA at University Hospital Dresden between January 2016 and September 2017 were randomised 1:1 to CS or IS groups.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Eighty patients received the allocated intervention (41 CS, 39 IS).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Suture time was significantly shorter in the CS group (median 12.0 minutes, IQR 10.0–17.0) compared to the IS group (median 22.4 minutes, IQR 15.0–28.0; OR 1.26, 95% CI 1.13 to 1.40; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Biliary complications, including bile leakage, were similar between groups (CS: 6/41, 14.6%; IS: 4/39, 10.3%; P = 0.738).
